Data availability and accessibility: 3 (unfettered access) 2 (access with barriersâ€¦e.g. need to ask agency for permission) 1 (need to contact authors) 0 (no author contact available)
Description of method: (+1) is the objective clearly defined (+1) are conclusions clearly supported by the study evidence (+1) method is clearly and sufficiently described
Description of data: (+1) data/population clearly described for each analysis (+1) the source of the data is clearly defined (+1) data processing, like outliers etc., is clearly defined
Description of tools: (+1) tools identified (+1) tools defined in detail, e.g. version number (+1) parameters of tools are described
Tool availability and accessibility: 3 (unfettered access) 2 (access with barriersâ€¦e.g. need to ask agency for permission) 1 (need to contact authors) 0 (no author contact available)
Replicability: Can those trained in the field can reproduce the study given the appropriate resources? (5) very likely to (1) very unlikely

Title of article: A randomized trial of blood donor iron repletion on red cell quality for transfusion and donor cognition and well-being
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper was conducted using data obtained from a separate study. Most of the necessary information to replicate this study was available in a supplemental appendix. The original study was extremely thorough and even replicated the primary analysis and descriptive statistics with two separate statisticians. The only minor criticism of the study protocol is that participant recruitment wasn't consistently done the same way; sometimes by email, or telephone, or mail. All of these methods have an effect on loss-to-follow up biases

Title of article: Ferritin-guided iron supplementation in whole blood donors: optimal dosage, donor response, return and efficacy (FORTE)â€”a randomised controlled trial protocol
Explanation ("Discussion"): Donor eligibility was assessed using a donor health questionnaire. To be eligible, donors must be in "good health", which is an ambiguous term. To determine the eligibility requirements within this questionnaire, a separate study was cited. This study provided some limited insite as to the fields of the health questionnaire, but overall it was ambiguous. Interestingly, two analysis softwares were used (SPSS and R). The version of SPSS was identified but the version of R was not described. There was little information on data processing, however this paper is only about a study protocol.

Title of article: Deferral rate variability in blood donor eligibility assessment
Explanation ("Discussion"): Two different statistical softwares were used, and it wasn't described which software performed which analyses. This study also used regression models, but there was no information on how the regression model assumptions were met (e.g. whether QQ plots or histograms were used to check normality). Additionally, the number of observations used for the regression models was not mentioned. There was no mention about variable selection for building multivariable models (e.g. backwards elimination, etc.). Overall the statistical analyses performed were not sufficiently described.

Title of article: Iron Replacement Therapy in the Routine Management of Blood Donors
Explanation ("Discussion"): Health data is very sensitive so reviewers would need permission from the ethics board of the hospital where the data was acquired from. The authors also do not mention the hospital where the data was collected; this information would have to be obtained by contacting the authors directly. The exclusion criteria does not seem detailed enough. Depending on the location, blood donors can be given permanent deferrals based on their specific health history. In the paper, they do not mentions the local blood center donor eligibility criteria, and they also do not mention the location of the blood donation center. It would also be beneficial to specifically mention whether all blood donations in this study were allogenic or not. Laboratory testing protocol is sufficiently detailed. Neither the data collection software nor the data analysis software used in this study were mentioned, however this study did not employ computationally advanced analysis.

Title of article: Intravenous iron for the treatment of fatigue in nonanemic, premenopausal women with low serum ferritin concentration
Explanation ("Discussion"): To access the data, reviewers would have to gain permissions from the local ethics committees of all participating hospital centers.The location of data collection was well described (and mentioned specific hospitals), however the time period that data was collected in was not described at all. For the inclusion criteria, the laboratory method for measuring serum ferritin and hemoglobin concentration was not described. There were also definitions in the inclusions and exclusion criteria that were not clearly described. There is ambiguity as to what the authors meant by "adequate contraception" in the inclusion criteria. Similarly, the exact "mental disorders" of the exclusion criteria were not mentioned, and neither was it described how they were assessed. The list of medications that would cause a participant to be unfit from participating in the study were also not thoroughly described. This study also included a "Short Performance Inventory" questionnaire, but there is not citation for where this questionnaire can be found, and neither is there detailed information on the content of the questionnaire. Neither the data collection software nor the data analysis software used in this study were mentioned. Otherwise, this study described the laboratory methods that they used.

Title of article: Coenzyme Q10 trapping in mitochondrial complex I underlies LeberÕs hereditary optic neuropathy
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper is published under open access. It is a molecular dynamics simulation study of mitochondrial complex I. All the simulation and analysis codes and data are openly available and maintained in an online repository (Zenodo). Therefore, this paper has good data availablility and accessibility. The study design involves comparing a mutated protein structure with the original wildtype form. The molecular dynamics simulation generated enough data for statistical comparison. In terms of potential of research practice, it is unlikely that the authors performed the simulation and the analysis blinded. However, since the analysis codes are made publicaly available, questionable statistical manipulation is unlikely. In the paper itself, the simulation and analysis pipeline were only briefly described. It would be hard to reproduce the results based on the methods section; readers probably need to go into the available codes to pindown the exact steps. This study is examining the structural characteristics and chemical kinetics of mitochondrial complex I in wildtype form and a mutant form relevant to Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy. The mutant itself is relatively common in the disease population. The based structure used for simulation was obtained from cryo-EM data. Overall, this is an open access paper with all of its codes and data available for download online. The only practical barrier to reproduce the research would be limitations of computation resources.

Title of article: The morphology of an infarct in nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper presents a pathological examination of the optic nerve of an patient with nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy. The raw processed pathological sample is probably kept at the institution, and the scanned pictures were included in the paper. However, the raw scanned pictures were not available online since it is a relatively old paper, from a time when online repository is not widely used. There is no comparison with normal optic nerve sample in the paper. The pathologist probably knows the diagnosis of the patient, so analysis was not performed blinded. The pathological processing and image acquisition and processing were well-described in the paper. However, some details were omitted (such as the concentration of staining used), but this is typical practice in medical pathology papers. This paper is only based on one patient, since it is really hard to obtain patient samples with the rare disease. The pathological processing chemicals and microscopes are common in medical facilities and not expensive. However, patient sample would be really hard to obtain for such rare eye disease.

Title of article: Finite element modeling of CNS white matter kinematics: use of a 3D RVE to determine material properties
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper presents a finite-element simulation study that investigates the material properties of CNS white matter under injury. The simulation code and raw results are not provided, but the authors mentioned the software they used with version number (one requires paid license). The parameters used for the model are justified with links to previous studies. The results are supported by the methods outlined.

Title of article: Attenuation of high-frequency (30Ð200_Hz) thalamocortical EEG rhythms as correlate of anaesthetic action: evidence from dexmedetomidine
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper studies the effect of anesthesia on rat field potential recordings. The conclusion is well-supported by the method outlined, with enough experimental details. However, the raw recordings are not openly available. The statistical analysis and tools used are also well-described. Some of the analysis softwares are commonly used and available, but require a license or subscription.

Title of article: Critical involvement of the thalamus and precuneus during restoration of consciousness with physostigmine in humans during propofol anaesthesia: a positron emission tomography study
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper studies the effect of anesthesia on human brain activity using PET scans. The conclusion is well-supported by the method outlined, with enough experimental details. However, the raw PET signals are not openly available. The statistical analysis and tools used are also well-described. The analysis softwares are freely available online on McConnell Brain Imaging Center's GitHub.

Title of article: Critical involvement of the thalamus and precuneus during restoration of consciousness with physostigmine in humans during propofol anaesthesia: a positron emission tomography study
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper studies the effect of anesthesia on human brain activity using PET scans. The conclusion is well-supported by the method outlined, with enough experimental details. However, the raw PET signals are not openly available. The statistical analysis and tools used are also well-described. The analysis softwares are freely available online on McConnell Brain Imaging Center's GitHub.

Title of article: An effector index to predict target genes at GWAS loci
Explanation ("Discussion"): Link to the data was provided in the article. All methods were described in detail with all code available online. The data preprocessing was not described in code. This paper can likely be reproduced. Only data preprocessing is missing, so there will be difficulty when we try to use different datasets to train the algorithm.

Title of article: Human genetics evidence supports two-thirds of the 2021 FDA-approved drugs
Explanation ("Discussion"): Data was provided in the article link. The data source is not described clearly. To use the software, we need to pay for the google storage. Although the tool accessibility is unclear, I figured out the alternative way to access the data. All other codes are clear.

Title of article: Selection, optimization and validation of ten chronic disease polygenic risk scores for clinical implementation in diverse US populations
Explanation ("Discussion"): The patients data were confidential. It will be hard to have the data. The protocol is not stepwise, and the code is not available. We donÕt know how they preprocess the data. The licence is need for accessing the tools. We do not have the data and code to reproduce the results.

Title of article: The performance of AlphaMissense to identify genes causing disease [Preprint]
Explanation ("Discussion"): Data was provided in the article link. However, we need license to access UK biobank data. The code for data preprocessing and performance evaluation is not available. We have the source of the data and tools, we need to write up the code by ourselves to reproduce the results.

Title of article: An Expanded View of Complex Traits: From Polygenic to Omnigenic
Explanation ("Discussion"): The data source is provided in the supplement file. We need to go to the original paper to find the data. The code for data preprocessing and performance evaluation is not available. Did not describe the tools used for analysis in detail, only names were written. We have the source of the data and tools; we need to write up the code by ourselves to reproduce the results.

Title of article: Cartography of opportunistic pathogens and antibiotic resistance genes in a tertiary hospital environment
Explanation ("Discussion"): The paper is accompanied by a "Reporting Summary" which Nature Research implemented to improve reproducibility and transparency in their published works. This Reporting Summary very clearly outlines the life sciences study design and makes it easy for the reader to understand the design limitations and reasons why a design method was selected for the undertaken research. All equipment, software and their respective versions used are explained in detail. The statistical analyses are described and significance provided, and analyses were "performed in R" but no packages were described (if used).

Title of article: Linking the resistome and plasmidome to the microbiome
Explanation ("Discussion"): Data are available through an accessible online database repository, and supplementary data and code for analyses that were not published in the main article are also available through OSF Home, a free open platform for data sharing, and which was provided by the private research partner. The methods section fails to accurately describe the a significant portion of the protocol (proximity ligation step) and which required the reader to go to the private partner's website to try to find. Additionally, some experimental steps are ambiguous such as the flow cytometry protocol for environmental cell counts was not described. The study conclusion appeared unrelated to the evidence collected and follow-up or additional evidence as to why this was observed or if this was a statistically significant conclusion was not provided. No discussion of the type of statistical analyses on the environmental sampling data were performed; statistical assumptions or significance statistics were not provided. The title is very general and grand.

Title of article: Metagenomic chromosome conformation capture (meta3C) unveils the diversity of chromosome organization in microorganisms
Explanation ("Discussion"): The paper is very detailed, and heavily cited by other studies reproducing and building upon their results. Conclusions are well-supported by the evidence. Although the software for statistical analyses is briefly mentioned, the statistical analyses are not in depth in the article.

Title of article: Widespread transfer of mobile antibiotic resistance genes within individual gut microbiomes revealed through bacterial Hi-C
Explanation ("Discussion"): The paper is also accompanied by a "Reporting Summary" which Nature Research implemented to improve reproducibility and transparency in their published works.

Title of article: Orchestrating chromosome conformation capture analysis with Bioconductor
Explanation ("Discussion"): This paper appears to be a summary of an entire book with a link to the open-source book. The attention to detail is very high and even individual steps are well-explained and written step-by-step. The concept of writing results, summaries, methods, and discussions in a step-by-step book style is cutting-edge and is an interesting path for future studies to take. There is also a reporting summary with this paper.

Title of article: Perceptual Relearning of Complex Visual Motion after V1 Damage in Humans
Limited restoration of contrast sensitivity with training after V1 damage in humans
Visual perceptual learning generalizes to untrained effectors
GABA and Glutamate in hMT+ Link to Individual Differences in Residual Visual Function After Occipital Stroke
Presaccadic motion integration between current and future retinotopic locations of attended objects
Organizing principles of astrocytic nanoarchitecture in the mouse cerebral cortex
Explanation ("Discussion"): (refining all my explanations)

Title of article: Glycogen distribution in mouse hippocampus
Image similarity and tissue overlaps as surrogates for image registration accuracy: widely used but unreliable
3D cellular reconstruction of cortical glia and parenchymal morphometric analysis from Serial Block-Face Electron Microscopy of juvenile rat
Single molecule microscopy reveals key physical features of repair foci in living cells
Single-molecule tracking reveals the functional allocation, in vivo interactions, and spatial organization of universal transcription factor NusG
Choosing the right label for single-molecule tracking in live bacteria: side-by-side comparison of photoactivatable fluorescent protein and Halo tag dyes
RNA polymerase redistribution supports growth in E. coli strains with a minimal number of rRNA operons
RNAP Promoter Search and Transcription Kinetics in Live E. coli Cells
Go with the FLOW: visualizing spatiotemporal dynamics in optical widefield calcium imaging.
Explanation ("Discussion"): The code and data used in the study are publicly available.  Supplementary movies were also available. The code is under an open license and can be used, but it cannot be modified without permission. The mouse population and their ages were clearly stated. However, I am not quite convinced by the statistical test that they performed, as well as the very small p-value provided given that they used only the average of the data, which was a small dataset. Furthermore, there are steps in the extraction of the Lagrangian Coherent Structures which were not quite clear.

Title of article: Optical-flow analysis toolbox for characterization of spatiotemporal dynamics in mesoscale optical imaging of brain activity
Explanation ("Discussion"): The experimental design revolves around a MATLAB toolbox developed by the authors for calculating velocity vectors on brain cortex activity using optic flow analysis. Evaluation is systematic, comparing obtained velocity fields with theoretical parameters and assessing algorithm performance against noise in widefield imaging data. However, more description would be helpful in discussing the methods. Mouse population details are sparse, understandably since the focus is on testing the toolbox. Despite open-access code and tools distribution, documentation gaps exist, notably in explaining methods and file retrieval, though a user manual is provided.

Title of article: Cortex-Wide Dynamics of Intrinsic Electrical Activities: Propagating Waves and Their Interactions
Explanation ("Discussion"): Data accessibility is limited and must be requested from the authors via email, while the methods and analysis are clearly explained and are align with the study's objectives. Population size is described within the paper, although more details regarding the mice used, such as age and sex, would be more helpful. Data preprocessing steps are explicitly outlined, including the specific toolbox and functions utilized. The description of tools, primarily code, is thorough and pertinent to the paper's aims. Imaging methods are well-defined. Although code is not readily available online, it can be obtained from the authors via a request, and a MATLAB toolbox NeuroPatt is open license, is linked for some analyses.

Title of article: Chronic, cortex-wide imaging of specific cell populations during behavior
Explanation ("Discussion"): The paper provides readily accessible data with a link provided for open access, without requiring authentication or formal requests. Methods are clearly articulated and aligned with the experiment's objectives, with surgical procedures and population size well-defined. Data preprocessing steps are explicit, although additional details about the mice used, including age and sex, would enhance clarity. Tools, predominantly code, are well-defined and relevant to the paper's aims, while imaging methods are thoroughly explained. Chemicals, camera specifications, and hardware details are sufficiently provided to aid in replicating the setup.

Title of article: Detection and analysis of spatiotemporal patterns in brain activity
Explanation ("Discussion"): The paper references data from another source, requiring requests to access it, and links to a separate paper for detailed data information. Methods are clearly articulated and align with the experiment's objectives, with population size and data preprocessing well-defined. However, additional details about the marmoset used, such as sex, would enhance clarity, though this information may be found in a referenced paper. Code availability is noted, with links provided, though the documentation lacks clarity regarding the codes' purposes and underlying method rationale, despite being accessible under license without explicit permission.

Title of article: Cancer Cell Membrane-Coated Nanoparticles for Anticancer Vaccination and Drug Delivery
Explanation ("Discussion"): Qualitative study with a lot of details on the experimental procedure, to the reagents used in every steps to the tools used in the experiment. Not 5/5 as some of the tools used are expensive but not a big deal. Image analysis can be done on open source software so overall pretty thorough and good study to follow

Title of article: Effective cancer targeting and imaging using macrophage membranecamouflaged upconversion nanoparticles
Explanation ("Discussion"): Qualitative study with a decent amount of detail, methods are just enough for this paper, you can still access them through other related papers (which seems to be to get more citations than anything) but reagent concentrations are severely lacking. Data analysis is mostly image based, so it is possible By taking the figures, but some data is not present (zeta potential?)

Title of article: Supported bilayer membranes for reducing cell adhesion in microfluidic devices
Explanation ("Discussion"): Paper describes their method to decrease cell adhesion in microfluidic devices using lipid membranes. They used different buffers to check how they affected cell adhesion. Methods and tools are thorough and nicely laid out. The data shown in the paper seem to be unavailable as is the case for most of these papers

Title of article: Transfer learning enables predictions in network biology
Explanation ("Discussion"): AKA Geneformer. Transfer learning is often ambiguous since the contexts between which to transfer don't necessarily have a one-to-one correspondence. They assemble their own dataset: Genecorpus-30M which is made available and immediately accessible from a huggingface repository. Finding all the tools may pose a challenge and take a while to compile, but should be doable, moreso than other paper of the type currently available.

Title of article: HyenaDNA: Long-Range Genomic Sequence Modeling at Single Nucleotide Resolution
Explanation ("Discussion"): HyenaDNA often gets lauded for the efforts that the authors went for making it reproducible for the user: they have virtual images that can be pulled, google colab notebooks to train your own, all pointing to the correct data sources. While the main conference paper can get a bit tecnical regarding the use of the proprietary Hyena Operator, it is otherwise clear. The human reference genome is used. Evaluations are diverse and come from multiple angles, but still paint a sound story when seen in conjunction.

Title of article: Sequence modeling and design from molecular to genome scale with Evo
Explanation ("Discussion"): An engineering-centric paper, Evo shows the potential of squeezing LLMs to their full potential through utilizing hybridized deep sequence architectures. The model is trained at an unprecedented scale, on whole prokaryotic and archaeal genomes. Leveraging the autoregressive property, it reveals insights at the single nucleotide level. It fancily uses its likelihood esitmation property across RNA, DNA and protein predictions, to predict diverse fitness of the evaluated sequences. Both the model and the weights are available online, setting the stage for it to be a widely used tool in the space. Model weights on huggingface and directly utilizable.

Title of article: DNA-Diffusion: Leveraging Generative Models for Controlling Chromatin Accessibility and Gene Expression via Synthetic Regulatory Elements
Explanation ("Discussion"): Uses machine learning diffusion models to learn underlying patterns of regulation from DNAse I hypersensitivity sites, to then generate sequences that contain this information. Model  and training scripts available on github.

Title of article: regLM: Designing realistic regulatory DNA with autoregressive language models
Explanation ("Discussion"): Leverages the HyenaDNA architecture to design cis-regulatory DNA elements (CREs).  Uses thorough experimental design and tokenization schemes to leverage HyenaDNA's potential to capture sequence dependencies to uncover regulatory insights. Code clearly pointed to and model weights provided.
